arrayConfiguration.label: Array Configuration
arrayConfiguration.help: Specify an array configuration. Currently the SKA has two arrays - SKA-MID (350MHz - 154GHz) and SKA-LOW (50MHz – 350 MHz).

0.help: Spectral Bandwidth of the observation. LOW supports eight channelization schemes in Spectral mode, each with a unique combination of frequency resolution and bandwidth. MID supports seven channelization schemes in Spectral mode, each with a unique combination of frequency resolution and bandwidth.

1.help: The continuum bandwidth of the observation. It must be fully contained within the selected band. Note: For LOW, the specified bandwidth must be equal to or larger than 5.43 kHz, which is the width of a LOW continuum channel. The specified bandwidth must be fully contained within the LOW band (50 - 350 MHz). It cannot exceed 75 MHz for the AA0.5 and AA1 configurations, 150 MHz for the AA2 configuration and 300 MHz for the AA* and AA4 configurations. For MID, note that for the AA0.5, AA1 and AA2 configurations, the specified bandwidth cannot exceed 800 MHz.

2.help: Maximum bandwidth available for Low AA2 is 150 MHz .

range.minimumChannelWidthError: Bandwidth must be larger than the channel width ({{value}} kHz)
range.contMaximumExceededError: Maximum bandwidth for this array assembly ({{value}} MHz) exceeded
range.rangeError: Bandwidth must be fully contained within the band

bitDepth.help: Select the desired bit depth for the data product.
bitDepth.label: Bit Depth

calibrator.desc: This is a likely observing strategy with calibration (assuming observation near transit, etc.):
calibrator.note: The choice of calibrators assumes that the target scan will be centred at transit.
calibrator.disclaimer: The use of these calibrators is not guaranteed.

comment.label: Comments on this strategy
comment.help: You can provide a comment on the observatory defined calibration strategy here.

calibrator.limitReached: Only 1 observation can currently be used for the calibration strategy.

centralFrequency.help: The central frequency of the observation. Must be within the selected band.
centralFrequency.label: Central Frequency

conflict.tooltip: Indicate whether there is a conflict of interest with this proposal

continuumBandwidth.help: The continuum bandwidth of the observation. It must be fully contained within the selected band. Note: For LOW, the specified bandwidth must be equal to or larger than 5.43 kHz, which is the width of a LOW continuum channel. The specified bandwidth must be fully contained within the LOW band (50 - 350 MHz). It cannot exceed 75 MHz for the AA0.5 and AA1 configurations, 150 MHz for the AA2 configuration and 300 MHz for the AA* and AA4 configurations. For MID, note that for the AA0.5, AA1 and AA2 configurations, the specified bandwidth cannot exceed 800 MHz.

elevation.help: Specify the minimum elevation angle at which the target will be observed. This value must fall between the horizon and the target's zenith elevation. If the specified elevation is outside this range, an error message will be displayed. The default minimum elevation is 20 deg for LOW and 45 deg for MID

email.label: Email
email.help: The email is a required field. The investigator will be invited to participate in this proposal using this email, so please ensure it is correct. If using the search functionality, the email should be of a registered user within SKAO systems. For example, @skao.int, @assoc.skao.int, or @community.skao.int.

groupObservations.label: Group
groupObservations.help: This field allows you to group observations. To create a group select the `New Group` from the dropdown and type a name of choice. 'None' is the default, in which case, the observation is not added to any group. After creating a group, observations can be added to the same group using the dropdown and selecting the created group name or a new one can be created.
groupObservations.toolTip: Add a group if observations need to be grouped.

notAvailable.help: Help text is not available in this field/page

imageWeighting.help:
Select natural, uniform or Briggs weighting.

For Briggs weighting, the robustness parameter can be set to a value listed below:

-2 (closest to Uniform weighting),
-1,
 0,
 1
2 (closest to natural weighting).
imageWeighting.label: Image Weighting

importFromFile.label: Import from file
importFromFile.descriptionTarget: Import targets from a CSV file. The file should contain a header row with the following columns: Name, Right Ascension, Declination, Epoch (optional). Each subsequent row should contain the target details. Ensure that the Right Ascension and Declination are in the correct format (e.g., HH:MM:SS for RA and DD:MM:SS for Dec).

lastName.help: Last name of the Principal Investigator or Co-Investigator.

listOfTargets.label: List of Targets
listOfTargets.toolTip: A list of targets can be created individually or imported from a csv file using the appropriate tab.

submit.help: Check to indicate that this individual can submit, edit and view the proposal.

name.label: Name
name.help: Name of the target/object. If you want to automatically populate the coordinates, then provide a name of a known object and use the resolve button to query SIMBAD first and NED if not found. However, you can provide an arbitrary target/object name which can contain any character and enter the coordinate values.

observingBand.help: Select the observing band to use for the observation. The available bands are 50 MHz - 350 MHz for LOW; and Band 1 (0.35-1.05 GHz), Band 2 (0.95-1.76 GHz), Band 5a (4.6-8.5 GHz) and Band 5b (8.3-15.4 GHz) for MID.
observingBand.label: Band

desc.1: These projects will be rapid responses to events that may be triggered either internal or external to the Observatory. ToO status may be recommended by the TAC or awarded by the Director-General. In some cases ToOs will have override status over other projects currently (or about to be) executing on the telescope.
desc.2: A JSP project requires both SKA-Low and SKA-Mid telescopes to achieve its science goals and may require observations to be executed contemporaneously.
desc.3: A project requiring SKA observations to be coordinated with another facility (either ground-based or space-based) with user-specified scheduling constraints provided. A common example of a CP will be a VLBI project, which will require the synchronized participation of a number of additional radio facilities.
desc.4: These projects require more than one proposal cycle to complete (e.g., long-term monitoring campaigns) but are too short in overall observing time, limited in observatory resources and/or scientific scope to qualify as a KSP.

proposalAttribute.help: One or more of these optional attributes may be selected to further refine the proposal.

proposals.name: Name
proposals.overviewTooltip: Tooltip for the card on the Overview

desc.1: Observing projects that require less time than a KSP, typically over a single time allocation cycle.
desc.2: Observing projects that require the allocation of significant observing time and resources, often over a period longer than a single observing cycle. Specific criteria that define a KSP will be described in each call for proposals.
desc.3: Time allocated by the Director-General outside the normal process of assessment by the Time Allocation Committee (TAC).

rank.hovering: Hovering - Click to select this rank
rank.label: Rank
rank.helper: Click on the center (0) or any segment (1-9) to set your ranking

0.title: Neutral
0.description: No preference or opinion. This represents a completely neutral stance with no positive or negative feelings.

1.title: Strongly Dislike
1.description: Very negative feelings. This represents the lowest level of preference with strong opposition or dislike.

2.title: Dislike
2.description: Negative feelings. This indicates a clear preference against this option, though not as strong as level 1.

3.title: Somewhat Dislike
3.description: Mild negative feelings. This represents a slight preference against this option with some reservations.

4.title: Slightly Dislike
4.description: Minor negative feelings. This indicates a very slight preference against this option.

5.title: Slightly Like
5.description: Minor positive feelings. This indicates a very slight preference for this option.

6.title: Somewhat Like
6.description: Mild positive feelings. This represents a slight preference for this option with some positive aspects.

7.title: Like
7.description: Positive feelings. This indicates a clear preference for this option with good positive feelings.

8.title: Strongly Like
8.description: Very positive feelings. This represents the highest level of preference with strong positive feelings.

9.title: Perfect
9.description: Absolute positive feelings. This represents the ultimate level of preference with perfect satisfaction.

suppliedType.help: The sensitivity for the observation in units of Jy/beam or K is used to calculate the integration time needed to reach this sensitivity. If the integration time of the observation is given, this is used to calculate the sensitivity that will be reached with this integration time.

suppliedValue.help: Add the required time, selecting the appropriate unit, to reach the desired target sensitivity or the required sensitivity which will be used to estimate the required integration time

tapering.help: Select value from the list. A circular Gaussian taper may be applied to the uv data. It specifies the FWHM of an image-domain Gaussian, in arcsec; tapering the uv data is equivalent to convolving with this image-domain Gaussian.
tapering.label: Tapering

taper.help: Select value from the list. A circular Gaussian taper may be applied to the uv data. It specifies the FWHM of an image-domain Gaussian, in arcsec; tapering the uv data is equivalent to convolving with this image-domain Gaussian.
taper.label: Gaussian Taper
taper.error: A value equal or greater than zero is required

targetImport.help: Upload a list of targets in .csv format in the reference system selected. Currently only ICRS is available so define targets in ra: 'hh:mm:ss.s' and dec: 'dd:mm:ss.s' format. Example is .csv file with name, ra, dec. Fields with incomplete row entry and duplicate target names will be removed when uploaded.

spectral.1:
In Science Verification, Spectral line products include: 

* Spectral line cube without continuum subtraction.
* If requested, spectral line cube after continuum subtraction.
* Model images per channel
* PSF images per channel
* Residual images per channel
* Calibrated visibilities averaged to 3.4 s and native channel width (to enable full verification of the imaging ODPs)
* Ancillary data product including Local Sky Model catalogue and QA report

continuum.1:
In Science Verification, Continuum data products include: 

* Calibrated visibilities averaged to 3.4 s and 21.7 kHz (to enable full verification of the imaging ODPs) 
* MFS image 
* Channel images for spectral index estimation as specified in 'channels out'. 
* Model images per channel * PSF images per channel 
* Residual images per channel 
* Ancillary data product including Local Sky Model catalogue and QA report
continuum.2:
In Science Verification, Continuum data products include: 

* Calibrated visibilities averaged to the specified values (to enable full verification of the imaging ODPs)
* MFS image+
* Model image
* PSF image
* Residual image
* Ancillary data product including Local Sky Model catalogue and QA report* Residual image
* Ancillary data product including Local Sky Model catalogue and QA report

+ The MFS images are generated with ...

pst.0:
In Science Verification, PST Flow through data products include: 

* Single or dual-polarisation beam-formed voltages requantised to the specified bit depth
* QA report
pst.1:
In Science Verification, PST Detected Filter bank data product include: 

* Filter bank data, averaged and requantised as specified in the panel on the left.
* QA report
pst.2:
In Science Verification, PST Pulsar Timing data products include: 

* Beam-formed voltages
* time of arrival
* residuals from the best-fit timing model for the pulsar, 
* updated ephemerids, and
* QA report
